__data__.text: A low pressure system originated in the northern Great Plains, US, and merged with a disturbance from the Southwest, growing large. Fueled by Arctic air and a western high pressure system, it moved eastward, becoming a massive low pressure system. By January 25, it had reached the Great Lakes, deepening and accelerating. Cold front warnings were issued as far south as Alabama, Georgia, and Arkansas. The system's leading edge, moving at 100 mph, brought blizzard conditions to the Great Lakes region, Michigan, Southern Ontario, and Upstate New York on January 26, due to moisture from the Lakes and strong winds.

The initial low pressure system expanded and merged with another disturbance, resulting in a massive system that moved eastward, bringing blizzard conditions to the Great Lakes region and heavy snow, hail, and sleet to northwestern New England, southern Quebec, and the St. Lawrence Valley. The system weakened in Maine and moved into Canada, while a second low pressure system formed in North and South Dakota, bringing snow and high winds to the Midwest and East Coast. This second system also caused severe snow drifting and low visibility conditions until January 30.

Two low pressure systems brought significant winter weather to various regions, with the first causing extensive snow, hail, and sleet in the Great Lakes region, northwestern New England, southern Quebec, and the St. Lawrence Valley. The second system formed in North and South Dakota, leading to snow and high winds in the Midwest and East Coast. Both systems resulted in severe snow drifting and low visibility conditions, affecting regions like Southwestern Ontario and western New York for five to six consecutive days and impacting travel, schools, and industries. Despite the storms' major consequences, they do not appear on the NWS's Regional Snowfall Index lists due to their wind-related impacts rather than uniformly high snowfall.

Two low pressure systems recently brought substantial winter weather to multiple regions, resulting in significant snow, hail, and sleet in the Great Lakes region, northwestern New England, southern Quebec, the St. Lawrence Valley, and parts of the Midwest and East Coast. The storms caused severe conditions such as snow drifting and low visibility, impacting travel, schools, and industries for five to six consecutive days. Despite the major consequences, these storms are not included in the NWS's Regional Snowfall Index due to their wind-related impacts rather than heavy snowfall. The areas with the highest snowfall accumulations were London, Ontario (68.6 cm), Quebec City (54.1 cm), Rochester (16.9 inches), Syracuse (13.1 inches), Ottawa (29 cm), and Montreal (26.5 cm). Smaller centers like Paisley, Ontario (127.6 cm), Oswego and Watertown, New York (22.1 and 18.8 inches respectively) also experienced significant snowfall. This snowfall is not considered in the US Regional Snowfall Index as it occurred in Canadian regions.

The dual blizzards caused severe conditions in the London/Lake Huron Region of Southern Ontario and Western and Central New York, resulting in blizzard conditions with visibility below 400 meters for up to 32 hours. This led to the closure of Highway 401 between London and sections to its east, as well as the complete closure of the New York State Thruway west of Utica for almost two days. During these closures, hundreds of people had to seek emergency overnight accommodation. In addition, thirteen counties in New York and numerous highways in Ontario's Lake Huron Region were closed or blocked by snow for two to three days.

The first blizzard led to the banning of vehicular travel on roads in thirteen New York counties and the closure of numerous highways in Ontario's Lake Huron Region. Over 20,000 Ontario students were stranded at school or in the community for up to three nights, and some schools remained closed for up to six days. The Rochester-area, Michigan, and Southern Quebec also faced road blocks, school closures, and stranded individuals. The second blizzard caused similar conditions in Montreal, Northeastern Ohio, and Wisconsin, with five Wisconsin counties closing all roads during the storm.

The second blizzard severely impacted Wisconsin, leading to the closure of all roads in five counties. Visibility conditions were so poor that snow plows had to be withdrawn from service in multiple areas, resulting in collisions and subsequent fatalities and injuries. The first blizzard caused at least 15 deaths in the US, including seven traffic-accident related, two heart attacks, one train-related, one pedestrian struck by a car, and one person trapped in their vehicle. Additionally, there were over 50 reported injuries from the first storm, which affected regions from the Midwest to New England. The second storm resulted in at least 19 fatalities across the US, with six deaths each in New York and Michigan, five in Wisconsin, and two in Pennsylvania.

The first and second blizzards resulted in a significant number of fatalities and injuries across several regions, including Wisconsin, the Midwest, New England, Ontario, and Quebec. In Wisconsin, the first storm led to school closures and contributed to at least 15 deaths and over 50 injuries, while the second storm caused five fatalities and additional injuries. Similarly, in Ontario, six people died during the first blizzard, and three more died in a car-tanker truck accident during the second storm. In Quebec, six people died during the first blizzard, but no fatalities were reported during the second storm. The causes of death varied and included traffic accidents, heart attacks from shoveling snow, pedestrians struck by vehicles, exposure to cold, and a train-related incident. The first storm also dropped up to 10 inches (25 cm) of snow in Wisconsin and northern Illinois, resulting in poor visibility and dangerous road conditions.

The first storm heavily affected Wisconsin and northern Illinois with up to 10 inches (25 cm) of snow, resulting in school closures. Three days later, the second, narrower storm hit southern and central Wisconsin, causing blizzard conditions, five fatalities in traffic accidents, and a 100-car pile-up. Authorities closed roads due to safety concerns, and some areas experienced extreme cold.

The first storm caused significant snowfall in Wisconsin and northern Illinois, resulting in school closures and hazardous road conditions. A few days later, a second, narrower storm hit southern and central Wisconsin, resulting in five traffic fatalities, a 100-car pile-up, and closed roads. Both storms produced extremely cold temperatures and high winds, causing damage to infrastructure and power outages in Illinois and Indiana. Specifically, Chicago experienced strong winds that caused damage to buildings and knocked out power to thousands of residents, while South Bend, Indiana, received 6 inches of snow. Green Bay, Wisconsin, experienced extreme cold, with wind chill temperatures dropping to -55°F (-48°C). A coal train accident in Indiana caused by high winds resulted in one death and two injuries.

After the previous storms in Wisconsin and Illinois, Indiana and Michigan were also affected by a subsequent storm on January 26. In Indiana, the northern third of the state, including South Bend, received 6 inches of snow, and high winds caused drifting snow, leading to hazardous road conditions and school closures. Central Indiana, including Indianapolis, experienced strong winds that triggered false fire alarms, damaged buildings, and cut power to thousands of households. In Michigan, the storm brought blizzard conditions to large areas, with wind-driven snow creating zero-visibility driving conditions and blocking highways with snow drifts. Only single lanes were kept clear on some Michigan highways, including the state's three interstate highways.

The storm in Michigan led to severe conditions including heavy snowfall and zero-visibility driving, causing the closure of all highways and roads in the Upper Peninsula and parts of the northwest Lower Peninsula, including Sault Ste. Marie. Only one airport remained open in the area. Additionally, numerous highways were blocked by snow drifts, resulting in abandoned vehicles and stranded motorists across the state. Thousands of schools were closed, and Sault Ste. Marie received a total of 17.5 inches of snow over five days.

The storm in Michigan resulted in significant snowfall and high winds, causing the closure of schools, businesses, and roads in various regions. Sault Ste. Marie received a total of 17.5 inches of snow, with an additional 8 inches during January 28-29. Cheboygan experienced 15-foot snow drifts due to strong winds from Lake Huron, leading to the closure of all facilities and residents staying home. Power outages occurred in Benton Harbor, and the roofing of a building in Grand Rapids airport was torn off. Some southwestern counties had schools closed for three days due to ongoing snowfall and drifting snow, with total accumulations reaching 15 inches.

In response to the storm, Cass County utilized a four-wheel drive military ambulance to distribute supplies and assist stranded motorists, while snowmobiles were employed in adjacent areas for food deliveries. The high winds in the Metro Detroit region resulted in severe damage, such as torn-off building roofs, including a high school in Livonia and the Livonia Police Department's communications antenna. The strong winds also forced General Motors and Chrysler to close down plants and caused most flights to be canceled or delayed. Despite the city's efforts to apply salt to arterial roads, the winds often blew the salt away and caused further snow accumulation.

After the storm, Cass County used a military ambulance to distribute supplies and help stranded motorists, while snowmobiles were used in nearby areas for food deliveries. The high winds in the Metro Detroit region caused significant damage, including torn-off building roofs and downed communication antennas. The strong winds also led to the closure of automobile factories and disrupted most flights. Despite city workers spreading 2,500 tons of salt on major roads, the salt was often blown away by the wind, resulting in further snow accumulation. This led to multiple pile-ups, including a 35-vehicle pile-up on I-96 and I-95, causing several injuries and highway closures. Oakland County reported over 100 traffic accidents, and other southeastern Michigan counties experienced a high volume of accidents, overwhelming their telephone switchboards. The storm resulted in four deaths statewide, two from traffic accidents and one from a pedestrian being struck by a vehicle. A second winter storm hit Michigan three days later, bringing an additional 4 inches (10 cm) of snow to Detroit and the Lower Peninsula.

The storm's aftermath included strong winds of up to 50 mph (80 km/h), leading to blizzard and near-blizzard conditions in various urban areas. This resulted in slow evening rush hours and numerous abandoned vehicles on major freeways. Many people sought refuge in makeshift accommodations, such as American Legion Halls, private homes, buses, and all-night restaurants. The second storm resulted in at least six deaths in Michigan and Ontario, including traffic accident fatalities and one exposure death. Schools in Southern and Northeastern Ontario were closed for a day or more due to blocked or closed highways. The London and Lake Huron Region of Southwestern Ontario was particularly affected, with cities and towns becoming isolated for two or more days.

The London and Lake Huron Region in Southwestern Ontario suffered the most, with several cities and towns becoming cut off for over two days. The storm caused five deaths in Ontario on January 26, including individuals struck by cars, one traffic accident fatality, a heart attack victim shoveling snow, and an exposure death. Another person died from exposure on January 27. On January 29, three individuals perished near Hamilton when a car collided with a jack-knifed tanker truck in heavy snow. A person from Huron County was rescued after being trapped in their car for 35 hours. The storm initially hit Ontario in Sault Ste. Meanwhile, Northeastern Ontario also experienced the blizzard's impact.

The blizzard began in Northeastern Ontario, specifically Sault Ste. Marie, on the evening of January 25, with reduced visibility and significant snowfall. Over the next few days, the city experienced multiple blizzard conditions, leading to numerous school closures and traffic accidents. The rest of Northeastern Ontario was hit around dawn on January 26, with strong winds causing high drifts.

The blizzard caused severe conditions in Sudbury, including 22.4 cm of snow, high winds, and 12 hours of whiteouts. This resulted in hazardous road conditions, with many school buses and cars getting stuck, including a family of five trapped for 22 hours and 58 students overnight at school. Due to the dangerous conditions, snowplows couldn't operate, and most schools and roads remained closed on January 26. Intercity transportation by car, bus, or air was also halted throughout the region, except for Highway 17 from North Bay to Ottawa.

The text describes severe blizzard conditions in Kapuskasing, London, and the Lake Huron region in Southwestern Ontario. In Kapuskasing, mail delivery was canceled due to extreme wind chill of -61°C. In the Lake Huron region, the blizzard lasted for up to six days, bringing heavy snowfall and high winds, which significantly reduced visibility. The blizzard first hit Sarnia and other coastal areas around 9:30 a.m. on Tuesday, January 26, and then moved inland. In London, visibility dropped to 200 meters by noon and to zero by 5:00 p.m., where it remained for 32 consecutive hours, making road conditions extremely hazardous. Most schools and roads were closed, and intercity transportation was halted, except for Highway 17 from North Bay to Ottawa.

The blizzard persisted for 32 consecutive hours in areas north of London, east of Lake Huron, and west of Kitchener, although with slightly milder conditions and shorter duration in most places. London received 45.6 cm of snow, Woodstock 40.9 cm, Exeter 48.3 cm, and Paisley 40.7 cm. Areas on the eastern edge, like Mount Forest and Kitchener, experienced blizzard-like conditions but with less snowfall, at 20.7 cm and 10.4 cm respectively. Mail delivery was canceled in Kapuskasing due to extreme wind chill, and visibility dropped to zero in London for 32 hours, causing hazardous road conditions, school and road closures, and suspension of intercity transportation, except for Highway 17. The blizzard first hit Sarnia and other coastal areas on January 26 and moved inland.

The first blizzard brought significant snowfall to Brantford, a city in the southeastern edge of Southwestern Ontario, with lesser amounts in Paisley and Wiarton. On January 28, minimal snowfall continued, but strong winds created low visibility in many areas. A second blizzard hit the region on January 29, with wind gusts up to 85 km/h, bringing 15.5-20.3 cm of snow over two days, and causing further reduced visibility on January 30. Most areas experienced four consecutive days of blizzard-like conditions.

From January 29 to February 1, many parts of the region endured successive days of blizzard-like conditions, with reduced visibility and cold temperatures. The wind and snow eased slightly on January 31, but significant snowfall continued, with Paisley receiving 11.9 cm, London 4.8 cm, and Wiarton 9.7 cm. Paisley was hit hardest, getting an additional 15.7 cm on February 1, bringing its seven-day snowfall total to 127.6 cm.

The blizzards that occurred from January 29 to February 1 brought substantial snowfall to the region, with London receiving 67.5 cm, Exeter 68.6 cm, and Wiarton 79.8 cm. Snow drifts were even higher, leading to impassable highways. In the London/Lake Huron Region, many provincial and county roads were quickly blocked by snow, and the low visibility caused the Department of Highways to withdraw their snow plows. Highways 4, 7, 8, 19, 23, 83 west of Stratford, and Highway 21 near Amberly were obstructed for an extended period, and it took crews over two days to clear the snow on Highway 21 near Amberly.

The first blizzard resulted in significant snowfall and drifts, causing impassable highways and blocked roads in the London/Lake Huron Region. Highway 21 near Amberly had "mountainous drifts" and was obstructed for over two days, while a long-lasting collision of vehicles occurred near Highways 7 and 22. The second blizzard on January 29 further blocked highways and roads, leaving several communities isolated, even those with open highways had only one lane available, and drifting snow persisted for up to three days.

The second blizzard caused ongoing highway obstructions and prolonged drifting snow, leaving only one lane open on some highways, including Highway 8 to Goderich, which was not fully cleared until February 1. Numerous police cruisers were stuck in snow drifts, and many police forces, including those in London and Woodstock, had to pull their vehicles off the roads due to zero visibility and high collision risk. On January 26 and 27, Highway 401 connecting London to other cities was blocked at various points, with hundreds of collisions near London exits, isolating these communities from the rest of the province as other transportation modes were also impacted.

The blizzard severely impacted other highways and transportation options, completely isolating London and Woodstock from the rest of the province. The most affected area was near London exits on Highway 401, where hundreds of collisions occurred. On January 26, vehicles were diverted to other highways, and the stretch was closed again during the second blizzard. The Premier of Ontario was stranded at a service center near Ingersol overnight and for most of January 27, along with around 350 other people. He and his driver managed to reach London in an airport bus after a 5-hour slow journey, during which they had to navigate through whiteout conditions, and many others were stuck at the service center for two nights.

The Woodstock Snowmobile Club assisted in rescuing stranded motorists on Highway 401 and transporting them to safety. Buses, airports, and trains experienced significant disruptions, with intercity buses delayed by 17 hours and some trains derailed or delayed. Rural areas, including the Lake Huron Region, faced extreme isolation due to whiteout conditions, leading to many county snow plows being pulled off the roads. The only reliable transportation mode was the train, although it also faced delays and disruptions.

Rural regions, particularly around Lake Huron, faced severe isolation due to heavy snowfall, causing many snow plows to be pulled off roads. Stranded motorists sought shelter in various buildings, including businesses and private residences, for extended periods, some for as long as 3 days. A hotel in Lucan housed over four times its capacity, and even the Canadian Armed Forces' helicopter supply mission had to be abandoned due to adverse weather. High winds also disrupted electricity in fifty areas across the London/Lake Huron Region.

Severe wind gusts in Bruce and Grey counties led to a power outage for several hours, affecting hundreds of farmers who had to milk their cows manually. With electric milk storage facilities not functioning and impassable roads preventing milk delivery, large quantities of milk were wasted. Although electricity was restored in some areas, many farmers still had to discard milk due to storage limitations and impassable roads. While some sources claim that most homes had electricity by January 27, others suggest that hundreds remained without power until January 28, when helicopters were deployed to assist repair crews, particularly in Clinton where at least 200 homes were affected.

Following the blizzard, around 200 homes in Clinton remained without power until January 28, when helicopters were utilized to deliver repair crews. The CAF conducted an aerial search to ensure no one was trapped in vehicles, while snowmobilers rescued a couple near Port Elgin. Many towns and villages remained isolated, with establishments closed, and police advising against traveling into the snowy countryside. Snowmobile clubs collaborated with police to assist in emergencies, such as delivering supplies to isolated farms and transporting individuals to medical facilities.

After the blizzard, snowmobile clubs in various areas, including Hanover, Port Elgin, and Southampton, collaborated with police to provide emergency assistance 24/7. They delivered essential supplies like food, fuel, and medications to isolated farms and transported medical patients and their medications to medical facilities. Snowmobilers also delivered food, blankets, and other necessities to stranded individuals. However, due to ongoing heavy snowfalls, even snowmobilers faced challenges in making deliveries in northern regions like Paisley by January 30. Around 20,000 students in the Lake Huron and London area, mostly rural students relying on school buses, were stranded at their schools or in nearby homes until January 28 or even a couple of nights after that. The local snowmobilers' efforts were widely recognized for their crucial role in helping those in need during the crisis.

The unexpected severity and duration of the blizzard in the Lake Huron region left school administrators unprepared, causing them to react differently. Some schools attempted to send buses in the late morning or early afternoon, but poor visibility forced drivers to return, with some buses getting stuck. A few students walking to their buses were even swept away by strong winds, emphasizing the importance of staying at school during such conditions. The Goderich Signal Star questioned why schools were not closed earlier.

The extreme severity and prolonged nature of the blizzard in the Lake Huron region took school administrators by surprise, leading to varied reactions. Some schools tried to send buses in the morning or early afternoon, but poor visibility forced drivers to turn back, with some buses getting stuck. A number of students attempting to walk to their buses were even swept away by strong winds, highlighting the importance of staying at school.

Some school boards postponed buses for a few hours, hoping the blizzard would subside by mid- or late-afternoon. Meanwhile, principals considered early dismissals, but parents called, stating it was too dangerous, so they waited for conditions to improve. However, as this did not happen, plans were made for students to stay overnight by mid- or late-afternoon.

Bruce and Grey counties, located near the Georgian Bay area and under a storm warning, managed to get all but 880 students home. In towns and cities, high school students were often the ones stranded, with many staying at residents' homes, and some being transferred from high schools to these accommodations on January 27. For instance, in Clinton, a town of approximately 3,000 people, 600 secondary school students were housed in volunteers' homes.

In the Town of Clinton, with a population of around 3,000, 600 secondary school students sought accommodation in volunteers' homes during the blizzard. Food was a significant concern for elementary school students in remote settlements and rural roads, as stores in nearby villages ran out of essential supplies. However, food was delivered to these schools via snowmobile caravans and local farmers. The Canadian Armed Forces provided assistance the next day, delivering supplies to schools in need. At a school in Brucefield, 600 students and 24 teachers, stranded for 55 hours, received food and makeshift bedding from local sources.

During the blizzard, schools in Clinton, including Brucefield where 600 students and 24 teachers were stranded, used available resources such as drapes, gym mats, and carpeted floors for bedding. The community came together to provide blankets, medical supplies, and even doctors, which were delivered through snowmobile caravans and Canadian Armed Forces (CAF) vehicles. As the roads became blocked with snow, detailed coordination was necessary to transport students home, using buses, snowmobiles, and CAF tracked-vehicles. A school bus en route to pick up students on January 28 collided with an abandoned car, but with continued efforts, students were safely transported to their homes.

On January 28, a school bus en route to pick up students crashed into an abandoned car, but with the help of CAF tracked-vehicles, students were still safely transported to their homes. Despite a second blizzard on January 29, around 5,000 students in the Lake Huron Region were taken home before the weekend. Rural schools in Perth, Huron, Bruce, and Grey counties remained closed until February 2 or 3, while those in Middlesex (excluding London) reopened on February 1. Urban schools in these counties were already open by January 28 or 29 for in-town students who could reach them.

After the school bus accident on January 28, schools in rural areas of Perth, Huron, Bruce, and Grey counties remained closed until February 2 or 3, while urban schools in these counties reopened by January 28 or 29. However, in the eastern part of Southwestern Ontario, Waterloo County schools in Kitchener and Brantford areas were closed until January 31 due to high winds causing drifting snow, whereas Brant County schools reopened on January 28. In contrast, London experienced severe snow accumulation on January 26, leading to a state of emergency declaration by the Mayor. The heavy snowfall caused major traffic disruptions, with cars and plows getting stuck, and even four cars on railway tracks, requiring the railway to halt trains. The emergency declaration enabled Canadian Armed Forces (CAF) assistance and use of their vehicles to help the situation.

Following the severe snowstorm in London, the Mayor declared a state of emergency to enable Canadian Armed Forces (CAF) assistance, who provided vehicles such as heavy-duty trucks, jeeps, and ambulances for their own usage and to loan to the City of London. The CAF's vehicles were used for tasks like transporting sick individuals to medical facilities and searching for stranded car occupants. Due to the heavy snowfall, buses were taken off the road, and a two-horse open sleigh served as public transportation in downtown London. Citizens also loaned their four-by-four vehicles to the police for emergency response.

After the snowstorm in London, buses were removed from service due to rapid snow accumulation, and a two-horse sleigh served as public transportation in the city center. Universities, colleges, factories, and businesses closed for two to three days. Snow removal efforts allowed buses to resume service on most routes by January 28. London's radio stations provided continuous weather updates and facilitated community communication for emergency assistance during the storm.

During the snowstorm, London's radio stations provided continuous weather updates and enabled community communication for emergency assistance by allowing phone calls on air. However, due to the high volume of calls, there were delays in phone service in London, Brantford, and other centers. The city's courts and offices closed for two days but resumed operations on January 28. In Toronto, the blizzard lasted for two to three hours, causing visibility issues in central and northern areas, while other places had around 400 meters of visibility. The snowfall, along with strong winds, hit during the afternoon rush hour.

The snowstorm in Toronto resulted in hundreds of accidents, including multiple pile-ups and a 19-vehicle collision involving a school bus. The freeways were blocked for several hours, with many drivers abandoning their cars. One person died, and 20 were injured. Bus services were significantly delayed, leaving thousands of subway riders stranded. The situation was so severe that subway trains had to hold off from unloading passengers to prevent overcrowding. This event surpassed all previous storm-related incidents in Toronto.

The second snowstorm on January 29 brought poor driving conditions, low visibility, and significant snowfall to southern Ontario, although not as many accidents occurred as in Toronto. Windsor, at the southwestern end of the region, had less snow but faced near-blizzard conditions due to strong winds, causing transportation disruptions, damaged infrastructure, and suspended bus services. This storm's impact, although different, was still severe in certain areas.

The second snowstorm on January 29 severely impacted certain areas of southern Ontario, with Windsor experiencing near-blizzard conditions and 10.4 cm of snow, leading to low visibility, numerous accidents, stranded vehicles, and power outages. Although Hamilton received less snow (3.0 cm) on January 26, visibility was significantly reduced, affecting highways and roads. The Niagara Peninsula saw varying snowfall amounts, but St. Catharines and Welland received 10-11 cm mainly on January 27. Central and eastern Ontario were also affected, but the text does not provide specific details.

The second snowstorm on January 29 added 11.0 cm of snow in Hamilton, following the initial 3.0 cm earlier in the month, causing reduced visibility and accidents. Central and eastern Ontario, east of Georgian Bay, received a total of 40.9 cm of snow over January 26, 27, and 28-29, leading to hazardous conditions, stranded vehicles, and highway closures due to strong winds and a multi-vehicle pile-up.

A massive pile-up involving 20 cars occurred on Highway 400 near Barrie, leading to its closure, as well as the closure of many other highways in the area. In Barrie and Simcoe County, many students were stuck at their schools overnight, and the Governor-General of Canada was trapped in Orillia due to a snowbound train. In Ottawa, an advance wave of the storm brought near-blizzard conditions, reduced visibility, and strong winds, causing traffic slowdowns, road closures, and school cancellations in rural areas for up to three days.

The 401 highway was closed for ten hours near Cornwall due to a multi-tractor trailer collision, resulting in many cars in the ditches. Two winter storms hit the area, with the first causing minimal impact in Kingston and higher levels of drifting snow in Picton, resulting in school closures for a day. The second storm brought near-blizzard conditions and a 12-vehicle pile-up on Highway 401 in Gananoque. Meanwhile, northeastern Ohio was also affected.

A severe blizzard, as confirmed by the National Weather Service, hit northeastern Ohio on the morning of January 26, causing significant disruptions. The storm brought an average of 2 inches (5.1 cm) of snowfall, with certain areas east of Cleveland receiving up to 12 inches (30 cm). High winds, ranging from 80 to 100 mph (130 to 160 km/h), resulted in multiple car pile-ups, including a 13-vehicle and a 15-vehicle collision. The AAA reported approximately 350 calls for assistance due to dead car batteries and engines filled with snow. Driving conditions were so dangerous that 2,000 people were stranded in Cleveland overnight. The Ohio Turnpike reduced its speed limit to 40 mph (64 km/h) and prohibited trailers to ensure safety.
The blizzard in northeastern Ohio led to 2,00

The blizzard in northeastern Ohio resulted in 95 traffic accidents in Akron, with most occurring near Dayton where high winds caused a tractor trailer to tip over. Similarly, Cincinnati experienced strong gusts that reached 60 mph, leading to hazardous driving conditions and various structural damages, such as downed wires, blown-off roofs, and shattered windows. The Ohio River also saw 6-foot waves that caused a barge to sink. Meanwhile, in Pennsylvania, there were similar weather-related issues, although the text does not provide specific details.

The blizzard in Dayton, Ohio, caused severe damage to a car dealership and resulted in injuries from flying debris in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The storm in Pittsburgh, as confirmed in the US Government's Weekly Weather Report, brought gale-force winds of up to 67 mph, freezing temperatures, and heavy snowfall. The high winds resulted in structural damages, downed power lines, and hazardous road conditions, causing multiple accidents and injuries. While the text does not provide specific details, similar weather-related issues were reported in other parts of Pennsylvania.

The extreme weather conditions, including strong winds, heavy snowfall, and icy roads, led to numerous accidents in Western Pennsylvania, prompting road crews to work overnight to improve road safety. The AAA in Western Pennsylvania received over 2,000 calls for assistance, mainly due to cars failing to start from the intense cold. In northwestern Pennsylvania, schools in Erie and six adjacent counties closed for two days due to the inclement weather. While Erie only received 1.4 inches of snow on January 26, an additional 8.9 inches accumulated by January 29, leading to the closure of Interstate 90 and hazardous driving conditions on Interstate 79.

The first blizzard in Pennsylvania resulted in two fatalities: one person died from carbon monoxide poisoning after being trapped in her car in a snow drift, and another died in a head-on collision. The second storm primarily affected western Pennsylvania, causing icy roads, slow-moving traffic, and skidding accidents that resulted in additional fatalities. Meanwhile, West Virginia and Virginia experienced high winds that caused damage, including blowing off roofs, breaking trees, and knocking down power lines, leading to temporary highway closures. One trailer overturned in Virginia, but no serious injuries were reported.

The storm caused a trailer to overturn in Maryland, but no serious injuries were reported. In Washington D.C., high winds resulted in roof damage to buildings, downed power lines, uprooted trees, and a car accident with minor injuries. Rain, hail, and strong winds were also present, and a tornado warning was issued in the Baltimore area but no funnel clouds were observed. (The summary retains the propositions that a trailer overturned in Maryland with no serious injuries, and that Washington D.C. experienced high winds that caused roof damage, downed power lines, uprooted trees, and a car accident with minor injuries. The summary also includes the information that a tornado warning was issued in the Baltimore area but no funnel clouds were observed.)

The storm brought various weather conditions such as hail, rain, and snow to several areas. In Laurel, hail the size of golf balls was reported. North Carolina experienced high winds, which resulted in damage to buildings, downed power lines, uprooted trees, and highway closures. A trailer overturned in North Carolina, but no serious injuries occurred. In New York, a 120 mph gust tore off the roof of a visitor center, and blizzard conditions with thunder and lightning were observed in western and central New York. A television station in Syracuse went off the air due to a lightning strike on a transmission cable. The storm caused a trailer to overturn in Maryland, but no serious injuries were reported, and a tornado warning was issued in the Baltimore area, but no funnel clouds were observed. In Washington D.C., high winds resulted in roof damage, downed power lines, uprooted trees, and a car accident with minor injuries.

The storm on January 27 in New York featured blizzard conditions with an unusual combination of thunder, lightning, and high winds, reaching 70 mph, causing significant reductions in visibility and the formation of large snow drifts. This led to hundreds of minor accidents, including a pile-up near Scottsville, and the closure of roads, including a 60-mile section of the New York Thruway, due to hazardous conditions and downed power lines.

After the storm closure on January 26, a major 18-vehicle accident occurred near Batavia, leading to the closure of the Thruway's 260-mile section from Buffalo to Schenectady. This resulted in thousands of travelers seeking refuge in various places for two nights and two days. In Warsaw, many people were housed in private homes, the hospital, firehall, courthouse, and bomb shelter, with 100 staff staying overnight at the hospital. Power was also cut off to 2,000 homes in the Warsaw area, and numerous towns and cities in central and western N.Y. were isolated for at least two days.

Following the storm closure on January 26, a power outage affected 2,000 homes in Warsaw, and many towns and cities in central and western New York were isolated for at least two days. With roads impassable, snowmobile patrols in Wyoming County searched for stranded motorists and provided emergency assistance. In the Buffalo area, State Police patrols were limited, and schools and businesses closed due to strong winds. In Syracuse, central New York, schools were shut for two days due to 10 inches (25 cm) of snow, with a total of 13.1 inches (33 cm) received during the five-day storm.

The Ithaca area experienced severe blizzard conditions due to high winds (50-75 mph) on the night of January 26, leading to school closures and hazardous road conditions with around 25 accidents. The winds also caused a power outage in a Livingston County salt mine, affecting 115 miners. Following this, two additional snowstorms hit New York: one in Buffalo with 6.0 inches of snow and another in Oswego, receiving 15.7 inches of snow, on top of the previous storm's 6.4 inches. The Thruway was temporarily closed but reopened later the same day.

On January 26, a blizzard hit the Ithaca area with high winds, causing school closures, hazardous road conditions, and a power outage in a salt mine affecting 115 miners. Two more snowstorms followed in Buffalo and Oswego, resulting in additional snowfall and the temporary closure of the Thruway. The blizzard led to two fatal traffic accidents in New York State and one death on Long Island. While New York City and Long Island received only a light dusting of snow, the Finger Lakes region experienced a severe blizzard with thunder and lightning, leading to early school closures. The blizzard lasted for almost three days, causing significant disruptions in the area.

The blizzard's intensifying winds and reduced visibility forced early school closures, allowing students to return home safely. The high winds caused damage to buildings and led to the closure of roads and schools in multiple counties. Due to the deep snow drifts, tow truck drivers were hesitant to remove stranded vehicles, obstructing snow plowing efforts. Despite the challenging conditions, emergency services continued to operate, with instances of a doctor using a snowmobile to deliver a baby in Hilton. Rochester was significantly impacted by the storm, accumulating 6.9 inches (18 cm) of snow, which formed large drifts.

The severe blizzard caused widespread closures in greater Rochester, affecting all schools, stores, factories, offices, banks, and government offices, which remained closed on January 27. Thousands of people were stranded in shelters, motels, or friends' homes, and many lost electricity due to damaged transmission infrastructure. Bus services were significantly limited, and all flights were canceled for two days, with the airport closing for 10 hours. Two local radio stations also stopped broadcasting because of the storm.

The blizzard on January 26 and 27 led to the cancellation of flights and the closure of the Rochester-Monroe County airport for 10 hours. Two local radio stations also stopped broadcasting. Many roads were blocked by stalled or abandoned cars, making it difficult for plows to clear the snow. The morning of January 28, three-quarters of the roads in Monroe County were still impassable, and visibility was limited. A second storm from Ontario and Michigan hit Rochester and the surrounding area in the evening of January 28, bringing strong winds and an additional 10.0 inches of snow over three days. This resulted in the closure of several highways and many suburban roads, and the cancellation of flights at the Rochester-Monroe County Airport once again. The Automobile Club of Rochester received a record number of service calls during this time.

The extended blizzard in west-central New York resulted in seven fatalities, including individuals who suffered heart attacks while shoveling snow, driving, or experiencing collisions. In Montreal, the leading edge of the blizzard brought near-blizzard conditions, heavy snowfall, strong winds, and white-out conditions for 16 hours. The blizzard caused significant disruptions in both regions, with numerous road closures, flight cancellations, and a high volume of service calls.

The blizzard in west-central New York and Montreal caused four fatalities in Montreal due to hazardous conditions, including icy roads and sidewalks that led to heart attacks and a person being struck by a train. The extreme cold caused temperatures to drop rapidly, resulting in over 100 accidents on the city's streets and expressways, made slick by a layer of ice under the snow.

The blizzard in west-central New York and Montreal led to severe road conditions, resulting in numerous accidents, abandoned vehicles, and closure of certain highways and expressways. The extreme cold made it challenging for ground maintenance crews to keep airport runways clear, leading to cancelled flights. Intercity bus service was also significantly impacted, while trains experienced delays. To alleviate some of the congestion, authorities urged residents to use public transportation, which saw a significant increase in usage. Despite this, many streets were still clogged with abandoned vehicles, but traffic improved slightly during the afternoon rush-hour.

The blizzard caused significant disruptions in west-central New York and Montreal, including cancelled intercity bus service for a day and a half and delayed trains, particularly those coming through Ontario, which were 7.5 hours late. The storm also affected the Port of Montreal, banks, stores, restaurants, and theaters, resulting in minimal business. Most workers made it home by the evening of January 27, leading to few check-ins at downtown hotels. All schools in Montreal and surrounding areas were closed, and some areas experienced power outages. The storm extended to southwestern Ontario and Quebec City, causing moderate winds, heavy snowfall, low visibility, and road closures in Montreal's South Shore. Flight cancellations also occurred on January 30.

The blizzard severely impacted southeastern Quebec, Eastern Townships, and Quebec City, causing numerous accidents, taking hours for police to respond. The Trans-Canada Highway had a pile-up of four transport trucks near Drummondville, and 60 motorists were stranded due to blocked exits and inoperable snow-clearing equipment. Quebec City received significant snowfall and experienced near-white-out conditions for 10 hours. The storm caused road closures, flight cancellations, and power outages, resulting in minimal business and school closures.

The blizzard greatly disrupted transportation in Quebec City, leading to school closures, suspended ferry service, and closed airports and highways, including tolled ones. Two additional fatalities occurred in Quebec due to the storm. A second storm hit Quebec City on January 30 with heavy snowfall and reduced visibility. The blizzard also severely affected New England, causing whiteout conditions and near blizzards in several areas.

The blizzard severely impacted New England on January 27, causing near blizzard conditions in parts of New Hampshire, Vermont, northern Connecticut, and most of Maine. The National Weather Service (NWS) declared it as the first major blizzard in Vermont in many years, accompanied by a wind chill factor of -40 to -50F (-40 to -46C). Vermont received 5 to 24 inches (13 to 61 cm) of snow, leading to school closures and halted highway plowing, with reduced speed limits on Interstate Highways. Bus services were delayed by approximately 30 minutes.

The blizzard of January 27 had significant effects in Massachusetts, including cold winds, low visibility, and icy highways that caused numerous accidents and stranded vehicles in Boston. In contrast, Maine experienced less severe conditions, avoiding actual blizzard conditions, but still suffered damage to the Portland Yacht Club's pier and several others due to strong winds, low tide, and sea-ice. Meanwhile, Bangor, Maine had a severe drop in temperature, and maritime Canada saw the storm's strength decrease as it reached southern New Brunswick and Nova Scotia.

In maritime Canada, the storm's intensity decreased as it moved through southern New Brunswick and Nova Scotia. Saint John experienced brief snow showers, strong winds, and a substantial drop in temperature, while Halifax received snow and had a similar temperature decrease. Overall, the storm's impact in Canada was less severe compared to Massachusetts.
